label: 240. Statement of W.H. Dowdey -- June 26, 1865
description: Third certified statement from the former overseer concerning rice taken from James Ferguson's Dockon Plantation.  The note was apparently used in defense of Thomas Ferguson's petition to reclaim or be remunerated for the confiscated rice.  1p. June 26, 1865.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value: I William H. Dowdey, of the City of Charleston, State of South Carolina, hereby must solemnly certify and state that I have been employed as Overseer and Agent by James Ferguson Esqr., for his plantation on Cooper River, in the parish of St. John's Berkeley, known as the "Dockon" Plantation, that the said James Ferguson Esqr. is an old gentleman, eighty three years of age, blind and very infirm, that he James Ferguson Esqr was advised by his physician to leave the said plantation on account of his health; in consequence whereof I Wm H Dowdy was left in charge of the entire estate; that the said James Ferguson Esqr was never in the service of the Rebellion, nor by any act rendered assistance thereto; that on or about the 26th day of May 1865 Eleven hundred and eighty five bushels of Rough Rice belonging to the said James Ferguson Esqr was brought down and taken away without his consent from said place by parties belonging to the United States Forces under the direction and [illegible] of J. C. Malloney; that the said Rice was placed aboard the sloop Julia, D G Hough Master, and put in Bennett's Mill and is the same lot alluded to in the annexed Receipt, all of which is within my personal knowledge and [illegible].   Witness  Charleston, June 26th 1865.
